awd_titl_txt: Workshop: Exploring Quantum Phenomena and Quantum Matter in Ultrahigh Magnetic Fields; September 21-22, 2017, Alexandria, VA
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description:
This grant supports a workshop on September 21-22, 2017 in Alexandria, Virginia. The workshop discusses frontier areas of materials research, especially quantum phenomena and quantum matter, that will open up if magnetic fields well beyond the current state-of-the art become available. The workshop facilitates interaction, knowledge exchange, and collaboration among participants. The discussions focus on the challenges in the research field, as well as how the materials research community can better articulate the importance of the quantum phases of matter accessible in strong magnetic fields. High magnetic fields have major impacts in many areas of fundamental research, as well as applied areas such as medical technology, transportation, and power generation.

Technical Description:
High magnetic fields have led to a large body of exciting results in quantum matter. Examples include quantum Hall effects and the rich assortments of many-body states at distinct fractional fillings, new Landau level phenomena in graphene, novel dimer states in quantum magnets, novel excitations in topological quantum matter, and vortex liquid states in cuprate superconductors. This workshop discusses scientific frontiers that will be opened up if magnetic fields beyond the current state-of-the art (45 tesla for stead-state field and 100 tesla for pulsed filed) become available. The scientific case for having a new large-scale instrument/facility that includes high magnetic fields is discussed.

por.por_cntn:
Workshop: A workshop entitled “Exploring quantum phenomena and quantum matter

in ultrahigh magnetic fields,” was held on Sep 21, 22, 2017 at the new NSF headquarters, Alexandria. There were 22 speakers and 15 other participants. The talks ranged from opportunities in graphene, topological quantum materials including Dirac Weyl semimetals, synthethic materials, spin liquid frustrated magnets, and 2D materials (the program of talks is included in Appendix 2). There were also talks on current state-of-the art magnet technology.

The major question discussed in the 2 panels was the choice between aiming for a pulsed field capable of reaching 150 Tesla or for a DC magnet capable of reaching 60 Tesla. Although both prospects attracted strong, enthusiastic support, neither side was dominant. The participants recognized the scientific and engineering challenges involved. A consensus developed that we should be cautious about simply aiming for the highest achievable pulsed field without clarification about the scientific goals and opportunities. The workshop participants, while clearly highly enthusiastic about the high field targets, did not come to a firm decision supporting one case versus the other. The emerging consensus is that we should not build a pulsed field facility that would be difficult to integrate with closely related experimental techniques (i.e. a stand-alone facility with no clear scientific goals). There exist pulsed field facilities that have had little scientific impact (despite several decades of operation).An interesting compromise discussed is to achieve both a DC magnet achieving 60 Tesla and a pulsed field capable of reaching 130 Tesla. This dual goal appears to be achievable in the next decade.

We draw attention to the recent intense interest in the plasma fusion energy community in using high-Tc superconducting magnets based on REBCO (rare-earth barium copper oxide) tapes in future designs of compact fusion reactors such as the SPARC project at MIT. The magnets with fields up to 25 Tesla may enable achieve breakthrough ignition in room-sized reactors. The interest may accelearate progress in high-Tc superconducting magnets.

Final Report: The PI with the assistance of Professor Lu Li (Univ. Michigan) has written a 30-page booklet formal report on the workshop findings (cover in Appendix 1). A limited number of copies will be printed and made available to the public after the go-ahead is issued by NSF contract monitors.
